questions.question: A 30-year-old woman comes to the clinic with a severe respiratory infection. The physician explains the body's immune response, detailing the roles of different immune systems in fighting infections. Which of the following statements about innate and acquired immunity, as explained by the physician, is false?

options.A: Innate immunity provides a rapid response to infection without prior exposure to the antigen.
options.B: Acquired immunity develops over time and requires prior exposure to the antigen.
options.C: Innate immunity has immunological memory and can recognize specific antigens.
options.D: Acquired immunity involves T cells and B cells, which are specific to particular pathogens.

questions.explanation: antigens. Immunity Acquired/Adaptive Immunity Inherent resistance to infection from birth Resistance to infection developed over a lifetime Rapid immune response, occurring in minutes Immune response takes days to develop No prior exposure to the antigen needed (Option A ruled out) Requires prior exposure to the antigen (Option B ruled out) Limited diversity, operates within a restricted set of reactions More diverse and specialized in responses Lacks immunological memory Immunological memory is present Recognizes microbial antigens shared by many microbes (pathogen-associated molecular patterns) Recognizes antigens specific to each microbe Host cell receptors are non-specific (e.g., Toll-like receptors) Host cell receptors are specific (e.g., T and B cell receptors) (Option D ruled out) Components of Innate Immunity Physical barriers such as skin and mucosa Physiological barriers (e.g., body temperature) Phagocytic cells (e.g., neutrophils) Natural killer (NK) cells Other lymphocyte subsets ( γδ T cells, NK-T cells) Marginal-zone and B-1 B cells Mast cells, macrophages, dendritic cells Complement pathways (alternative and mannose-binding) Fever and inflammation responses Normal flora Cytokines: TNF- α , various interleukins, IFN- α , β , and TGF- β Acute phase reactant proteins (APRs) Components of Acquired Immunity T cells B cells Classical complement pathway Cytokines (e.g., IL-2, IL-4, IL-5, IFN- γ ) Reference: Apurba Sastry Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition Page 134

questions.question: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with signs of infection. The physician discusses the components of his immune system that are involved in the initial defence against pathogens. Which of the following is NOT a component of innate immunity, as explained by the physician?
questions.explanation: mannose-binding pathways are part of innate immunity. Components of Innate Immunity Anatomical and Physiological Barriers: Skin, mucosal surfaces, body temperature, pH, and secretions act as first-line defenses against microbes. Phagocytes : Neutrophils, macrophages, and monocytes engulf and destroy microbes in three steps—engulfment, lysosome fusion, and microbial killing. (Option B ruled out) Natural Killer (NK) Cells : These lymphocytes target and kill virus-infected and tumor cells. (Option C ruled out) Other Lymphocyte Classes : Includes γδ T cells, NK-T cells, B-1 cells, and marginal-zone B cells, which bridge innate and adaptive immunity. Mast Cells : Found in mucosal linings; release histamine and cytokines upon activation to trigger inflammation. Dendritic Cells : Initiate inflammation and transport antigens to lymph nodes to activate T cells, linking innate and adaptive immunity. Complement Pathways : Alternative and mannose-binding pathways mediate microbial lysis, inflammation, and stimulate acquired immunity. (Option A ruled out) Inflammatory Response : Involves vasodilation, plasma leakage, phagocyte recruitment, and destruction of microbes at infection sites. Normal Resident Flora : Competes with pathogens for resources and produces antibacterial substances. Cytokines : Includes TNF- α , interleukins, interferons, and TGF- β , which mediate immune responses to infections. Acute Phase Reactant Proteins (APRs): Proteins like C-reactive protein, complement proteins, and fibrinogen increase during inflammation to support immune defense. Reference: Apurba Sastry Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition Page 133-136

questions.question: A 60-year-old woman with a history of cancer presents to the clinic for follow-up. She has been receiving treatment that involves the use of antibodies to target her tumor cells. The physician explains how her immune system can enhance the destruction of these cells. Which of the following cells are not involved in the mechanism described by the physician?
questions.explanation: destruction by immune cells. This is called Antibody-dependent Cellular Cytotoxicity (ADCC) . Neutrophils and macrophages can engage in this response, while eosinophils are particularly effective against larger targets like parasites. Additionally, Natural Killer (NK) cells are critical players, binding to the Fc region of antibodies attached to the target cells, leading to their destruction. Antibody-dependent Cellular Cytotoxicity (ADCC) Neutrophils Macrophages Eosinophils NK cells Mechanism : IgG antibodies bind to target cells via the Fab region, while the Fc region binds to Fc receptors on effector cells (e.g., NK cells), leading to target cell destruction. Target : ADCC targets cells that are too large for phagocytosis, such as parasites, tumor cells, or transplanted tissue. Antibody Types : Primarily mediated by IgG antibodies; in some cases, such as eosinophil-mediated killing of parasites, IgE antibodies are involved. Basophils are primarily involved in allergic responses and do not play a role in ADCC. Reference: Apurba Sastry Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition Page 198 What is Antibody Dependent Cell-Mediated Cytoxicity? » ADC Review

questions.question: A 35-year-old man presents to the clinic with symptoms of a severe bacterial infection. The physician discusses how the body's immune system recognizes and responds to pathogens. Which of the following statements about Pattern Recognition Receptors (PRRs) is TRUE?

options.A: PRRs are primarily found in the bloodstream and not on cell surfaces.
options.B: Toll-like receptors (TLRs) are specific for identifying viral organisms.
options.C: PRRs recognize microbial-associated molecular patterns (MAMPs) on pathogens.
options.D: RIG-I-like receptors (RLRs) are the main receptors for fungal recognition.

questions.explanation: pathogens. (PRRs) Present on the surface of host cells (e.g., phagocytes). (Option A ruled out) Recognize MAMPs (microbial-associated molecular patterns). Generally consists of conserved regions encoded by germline genes. Five types based on protein domain homology: Toll-like receptors ( TLRs ) identify bacterial organisms. (Option B ruled out) Nucleotide oligomerization domain (NOD)-like receptors ( NLRs ) It is also associated with pyroptosis Retinoic acid-inducible gene-I (RIG-I) -like receptors ( RLRs ) identify viruses. (Option D ruled out) C-type lectin receptors ( CLRs ) identify fungal organisms. Absent in melanoma-2 (AIM2)-like receptors ( ALRs ) recognize intracellular DNA. Toll-like Receptors (TLRs) Classical examples of PRRs, named after the fruit fly (Drosophila). Main receptors for inducing innate immunity. Binding of TLRs to MAMPs generates signals that: Activate transcription factors. Stimulate expression of genes encoding cytokines and enzymes. Involved in antimicrobial activities of innate immune cells. Location of pattern recognition receptors: Toll-like and C-type lectin receptors: Present on the cell membrane and membranes of organelles like endosomes. RIG and NOD receptor: They are cytoplasmic Floating around

questions.question: A 9-year-old girl presents with recurrent fevers, skin rashes, and neurological symptoms. The physician is considering various autoinflammatory disorders associated with dysregulated type I interferon signalling. Which of the following is NOT a type of interferonopathy?
questions.explanation: associated with IL-6 ) but not classified as interferonopathy. Interferonopathies Interferonopathies are a group of rare, genetically defined autoinflammatory disorders characterized by dysregulation of the type I interferon (IFN) signalling pathway. These conditions often manifest with systemic inflammation and a distinct IFN signature detectable in peripheral blood. The most notable types include: CANDLE/PRAAS (Chronic Atypical Neutrophilic Dermatosis with Lipodystrophy and Elevated Temperature / Proteasome-Associated Autoinflammatory Syndrome) (Option A ruled out) SAVI (Stimulator of Interferon Genes-Associated Vasculopathy with Onset in Infancy) (Option B ruled out) AGS (Aicardi-Goutières Syndrome) (Option C ruled out) These disorders typically arise from mutations in specific genes that affect the immune response, leading to an overactive or improperly regulated interferon response. Etiopathogenesis The pathogenesis of interferonopathies involves genetic mutations that disrupt normal interferon signalling pathways. These mutations can lead to: Constitutive activation of the interferon pathway due to defective regulation. Altered responses to nucleic acid stimuli, which may involve intracellular receptors like cGAS and STING. Phenotypic heterogeneity, where different mutations can result in varying clinical presentations and disease severity. Genetic Mutations PSMB8, PSMB9, and PSMA3 are associated with CANDLE syndrome. IFIH1 and DDX58 are linked to other interferonopathies. These mutations often lead to clinical features such as skin rashes, neurological symptoms, and systemic inflammation. Clinical Features Dermatological manifestations: Rashes, lipodystrophy, chilblains, and livedo reticularis. Neurological involvement: Symptoms can range from developmental delays to severe neurological deficits. Systemic symptoms: Fever, myalgia, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, and signs of chronic inflammation. The clinical presentation is often diverse and can overlap with other autoimmune or inflammatory diseases, complicating diagnosis. Diagnosis: Confirmed through clinical evaluation, genetic testing for specific mutations, inflammatory marker levels, and neuroimaging if neurological symptoms are present. Management: Focuses on symptom alleviation, complication prevention, and targeted therapies to inhibit the overactive interferon response. Reference: Type I Interferonopathies in Children: An Overview - PMC Frontiers | Type I Interferonopathies in Children: An Overview Autoinflammatory type I interferonopathies: CANDLE/PRAAS, SAVI and AGS Interferonopathies masquerading as non-Mendelian autoimmune diseases

questions.question: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic after experiencing frequent infections. The physician explains the roles of various lymphoid organs in his immune system. Which of the following statements about primary and secondary lymphoid organs is FALSE?

options.A: The thymus is responsible for the maturation of T cells.
options.B: The spleen filters blood-borne antigens and activates T and B cells.
options.C: Bone marrow is the primary site for B cell maturation.
options.D: Lymph nodes are primarily involved in hematopoiesis.

questions.explanation: Primary Lymphoid Organs Secondary Lymphoid Organs Bone Marrow: Origin of all blood cells from pluripotent hematopoietic stem cells (process called hematopoiesis). Hematopoiesis shifts to bone marrow from liver after fetal life, eventually confined to axial bones after puberty. Progenitor T and B cells develop in bone marrow; B cells mature here, while T cell progenitors migrate to the thymus. (Option C ruled out) Lymph Nodes: Filter antigens and activate T and B cells. Structured into cortex (B cell area), paracortex (T cell area), and medulla (rich in plasma cells). Spleen: Largest secondary lymphoid organ, involved in filtering blood-borne antigens. (Option B ruled out) Contains white pulp (T and B cells) and red pulp (site of RBC destruction). Thymus: Site of T cell proliferation and maturation. (Option A ruled out) Developed from the third/fourth pharyngeal pouch in embryonic life. Active during childhood, decreases in size after puberty. Thymic hormones (e.g., thymulin, thymopoietin) help attract and mature T cells. Central tolerance occurs here, removing self-reactive T cells to prevent autoimmunity. Mucosa-associated Lymphoid Tissue (MALT): Located in mucosal sites (intestine, respiratory, urogenital tracts) to protect against pathogens. Includes loose clusters of lymphoid cells and organized structures (e.g., tonsils, Peyer’s patches in intestines). Reference: Apurba Sastry Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition Page 169-171

questions.question: During T cell development in the thymus, immature T cells undergo a selection process. Which of the following statements correctly describes this selection process?

options.A: Positive selection allows survival of T cells that cannot recognize MHC molecules
options.B: Negative selection eliminates T cells that react with self-antigens
options.C: Both CD4 and CD8 markers are retained on mature T cells
options.D: Double-negative T cells directly transform into single-positive T cells

questions.explanation: CD3 molecule These cells then express both CD4 and CD8 to become double-positive T cells During positive selection, only 5% of cells whose αβ receptors recognize MHC molecules survive During negative selection, self-reacting T cells (2-5%) are eliminated by apoptosis Finally, surviving cells become single positive (either CD4+ or CD8+) mature T cells Defects in the AIRE gene impair the negative selection of T cells, leading to Autoimmune Polyendocrinopathy due to the survival of self-reactive T cells. T-Lymphocytes T Cell Development Stages 1. Double Negative Stage (CD4- CD8-) • Express CD3 molecule • 95% express TCR αβ • 5% express TCR γδ 2. Double Positive Stage (CD4+ CD8+) • Undergo positive selection (5% survive) • Undergo negative selection (2-5% eliminated) 3. Single Positive Stage • Either CD4+ or CD8+ T cells • Released into circulation Major T Cell Types 1. Helper T Cells (CD4+) • TH1: Secrete IL-2, IFN- γ , TNF- β • TH2: Secrete IL-4, IL-5, IL-6, IL-10, IL-13 • TH17: Produces IL-17, IL-22 2. Cytotoxic T Cells (CD8+) • Kill virus-infected cells and tumor cells 3. Regulatory T Cells • Express CD4, CD25, Foxp3 - Causes IPEX syndrome( Immune dysregulation , Polyendocrinopathy , Enteropathy, X linked disorder. • Suppress immune response Key Surface Markers • CD3: Universal T cell marker • TCR: Antigen recognition • CD4: Helper T cells, MHC-II restricted • CD8: Cytotoxic T cells, MHC-I restricted • Memory markers: CD45RO (memory), CD45RA (naive) Functions • Helper T cells: Coordinate immune response • Cytotoxic T cells: Direct cell killing • Regulatory T cells: Maintain self-tolerance • Memory T cells: Long-term immunity Option A: Positive selection retains T cells that can recognize MHC molecules Option C: Mature T cells express either CD4 or CD8, not both Option D: Double-negative cells first become double-positive before becoming single-positive Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology by Apurba Shastry, 3rd Edition, Page 172, 173, 174

questions.question: A research student is studying cytokine profiles of different T helper cell subsets. In the experiment, naive CD4+ T cells were activated and differentiated into different subsets. Which of the following correctly matches the T helper cell subset with its primary cytokine secretion pattern and major function? a. TH-1 1. IL-17, IL-22 x. Recruit neutrophils b. TH-2 2. IFN- γ , TNF- β y. Promote antibody production c. TH-17 3. IL-4, IL-5, IL-10 z. Enhance macrophage activation
questions.explanation: Cytokines Major Functions Role in Immunity TH1 Cells • IL-2 • IFN- γ • TNF- β • Activate macrophages • Enhance cell-mediated immunity • Stimulate cytotoxic T cells • Protection against intracellular pathogens • Mediate delayed-type hypersensitivity TH2 Cells • IL-4 • IL-5 • IL-6 • IL-10 • IL-13 • Promote B cell proliferation • Enhance antibody production • Stimulate IgE class switching • Promote eosinophil growth • Protection against extracellular pathogens • Mediate allergic responses • Involved in helminth immunity TH17 Cells • IL-17 • IL-22 • Recruit neutrophils • Enhance inflammation • Promote tissue inflammation • Protection at mucosal surfaces • Involved in autoimmune diseases • Contribute to inflammatory conditions Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology by Apurba Shastry, 3rd Edition, Page 173, 174 Pubmed

questions.question: Which of the following correctly describes the mechanism by which CD8+ T cells eliminate virus-infected target cells?

options.A: Secretion of antibodies that neutralize viral particles
options.B: Release of perforins and granzymes leading to target cell apoptosis
options.C: Production of IL-4 and IL-5 to enhance eosinophil recruitment
options.D: Activation of complement cascade to lyse infected cells

questions.explanation: cytotoxicity by release of perforins and granzymes. CD8+ T cells (cytotoxic T cells) CD8+ T-Cell Activation 1. Antigen-specific signal: • TCR binds to peptide-MHC I complex • CD8 interacts with α 3 domain of MHC-I 2. Costimulatory signal: • CD28 binds to B7 on target cells 3. Cytokine signal: • IL-2 (from TH1 cells) Mechanism of Action 1. Recognition Phase: • Binds to virus-infected or tumor cells • Recognizes antigenic peptides with MHC-I 2. Killing Phase: • Releases perforins (form pores) • Releases granzymes (enter through pores) • Induces apoptosis through caspase pathway 3. Resolution Phase: • Detachment from target cell • Can kill multiple target cells sequentially Types 1. Naive CD8+ T cells: • Circulating, unexposed to antigen 2. Effector CD8+ T cells: • Activated, cytotoxic function 3. Memory CD8+ T cells: • Long-lived • Rapid response to re-exposure Primary Functions • Elimination of virus-infected cells • Destruction of tumor cells • Defense against intracellular pathogens • Generation of immunological memory Option A: Antibody production is a function of B cells, not CD8+ T cells Option C: IL-4 and IL-5 production is associated with TH2 cells Option D: Complement activation is part of humoral immunity, not CD8+ T cell function Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology by Apurba Shastry, 3rd Edition, Page 173, 174, 187

questions.question: Which of the following represents the correct sequence of events in B cell-T cell interaction leading to antibody production?

options.A: B cells undergo class switching after CD40-CD40L interaction without requiring cytokine signals
options.B: T cells present antigens to B cells via MHC-II molecules
options.C: B cells process antigen, present via MHC-II to T cells, receive CD40L and cytokine signals
options.D: CD28-B7 interaction between B and T cells is sufficient for plasma cell differentiation

questions.explanation: cytokine signals Key Components Initial B Cell Activation 1. Antigen Recognition: • B cell captures antigen via surface IgM/IgD • Antigen internalization 2. Antigen Processing: • Processed into peptides • Loaded onto MHC-II molecules • B cell receptor (BCR) (IgM and IgD) • Surface immunoglobulins • MHC-II molecules B Cell-T Cell Interaction 1. Signal Generation: • Signal 1: Antigen presentation to TH cells • Signal 2: CD40-CD40L interaction • Signal 3: Cytokine stimulation 2. T Cell Help: • TH1: IFN- γ (IgG production) • TH2: IL-4 (IgE production) • TCR-MHC-II complex • CD40-CD40L • Cytokine receptors • Co-stimulatory molecules B Cell Response 1. Germinal Center Formation: • B cell proliferation • Somatic hypermutation • Class switching 2. Differentiation: • Into plasma cells • Into memory B cells • Antibody production • Affinity maturation • Immunological memory Outcomes 1. Immediate Response: • Antibody secretion • Different Ig classes based on cytokines 2. Long-term Response: • Memory formation • Enhanced secondary response • IgG, IgA, IgE production • High-affinity antibodies • Long-lived plasma cells • Memory B cells

questions.question: Which of the following cytokines and mechanisms are correctly associated with this isotype switch? γ stimulation leading to direct IgM to IgE switch β inducing direct IgE production without prior IgM synthesis

options.B: IL-4 and CD40-CD40L interaction leading to IgE production
options.C: IL-2 stimulation alone causes isotype switching

questions.explanation: IL-4 and CD40-CD40L interaction between T and B cells. This dual signal requirement ensures proper regulation of IgE production. Immunoglobulin synthesis and isotype switching is a multi-step process: Immunoglobulin Synthesis and Class Switching Process Key Features Requirements Initial Antibody Synthesis • First antibody produced is IgM • Later co-expression of IgD • Occurs in bone marrow • No T cell help needed • Gene rearrangement • VDJ recombination • Expression of RAG genes Class Switch Requirements • Occurs in germinal centers • Requires T-cell help • Involves DNA recombination • Irreversible process • CD40-CD40L interaction • Specific cytokines • AID enzyme activity • Switch recombination Cytokine Control of Class Switching • IFN- γ → IgG2a, IgG3 • IL-4 → IgE, IgG4 • TGF- β + IL-5 → IgA • IL-2,4,5 → IgM • IL-4,5,6 + IFN- γ → IgG • TH1 cells (IFN- γ ) • TH2 cells (IL-4) • Specific transcription factors • CD40-CD40L required for all switches Outcomes • Changed effector functions • Same antigen specificity • Different tissue distribution • Different half-lives • New constant region • Same variable region • Different Fc receptors • Different complement activation Option A: IFN- γ promotes switching to IgG2a and IgG3, not IgE Option C: IL-2 alone cannot cause isotype switching; CD40-CD40L interaction is also req No uired Option D: TGF- β promotes IgA production, not IgE; all B cells first produce IgM Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology by Apurba Shastry, 3rd Edition, Page 189, 190, 191

questions.question: A laboratory analysis reveals an increase in B cells with the expression of CD19 and CD20. Which of the following best describes the role of these B cells?

options.A: They produce antibodies in response to T-cell activation.
options.C: They are involved in cell-mediated immunity.
options.D: They secrete cytokines to modulate the immune response.

questions.explanation: type of lymphocyte involved in the humoral immune response. They originate in the bone marrow and are characterized by surface markers such as CD19 and CD20. Upon encountering an antigen, B cells can undergo clonal expansion and differentiation into plasma cells, which produce antibodies. They can also present antigens to helper T cells (CD4+) via MHC class II molecules, enhancing the immune response. Formation of B Cells: B cells originate from hematopoietic stem cells in the bone marrow. Differentiation Process : Hematopoietic stem cells differentiate into lymphoid progenitor cells. These progenitors develop into B cell precursors, initiating B cell lineage. Stages in Bone Marrow : Pro-B Cell Stage : Initial recombination of the heavy chain gene. Pre-B Cell Stage : Expression of µ heavy chain, starting light chain recombination. Immature B Cell Stage : Successful expression of IgM on the cell surface; undergoes selection for self-tolerance. Mature B Cell Development : Immature B cells that pass selection express both IgM and IgD, becoming mature naive B cells. Peripheral Circulation : Mature B cells leave the bone marrow and circulate in peripheral blood, ready for antigen encounter. Features of B Cells: Antigen-Specific Receptors : B cells express B cell receptors (BCRs) on their surface, primarily IgM and IgD , which bind specific antigens. Clonal Selection and Activation : Upon antigen binding, B cells undergo clonal expansion, resulting in a specific immune response. Differentiation into Effector Cells : Plasma Cells : Specialized B cells that secrete antibodies targeting the specific antigen. Memory B Cells : Long-lived cells that quickly respond to future exposures to the same antigen. Role in Humoral Immunity : B cells are critical for humoral immunity, as they mediate antibody production and provide immunological memory. B Cell Markers and Their Functions: CD19 Present throughout B cell development and maturity; used as a universal B cell marker. CD20 Expressed from the late pro-B cell stage onward; target for certain therapeutic antibodies. CD21 Complement receptor involved in B cell activation by enhancing BCR signaling. CD40 It is critical for interactions with T cells, enables antibody class switching for adaptive immune responses, and is also responsible for Anergy and self-tolerance. Immunoglobulin Markers : IgM and IgD Primary B cell receptors on mature, naive B cells. They directly kill infected cells (Option B) : This function is primarily performed by cytotoxic T cells (CD8+ T cells). They are involved in cell-mediated immunity (Option C) : B cells are primarily responsible for humoral immunity, while T cells mediate cellular immunity. They secrete cytokines to modulate the immune response (Option D) : Although B cells do release cytokines, this is a secondary function. Cytokine production is more characteristic of T helper cells and certain innate immune cells, which coordinate and modulate the immune response extensively. Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology by Apurba Shastry, 3rd Edition, Page 184-191.

questions.question: A patient's immune system encounters a new antigen, leading to the initial production of IgM antibodies by B cells. Over time, these antibodies become more effective at targeting the antigen. Which process in the germinal centres of lymph nodes primarily accounts for this improved antibody effectiveness?
questions.explanation: leading to the production of antibodies with higher affinity for the antigen. This occurs after the initial IgM response, resulting in the production of IgG (or other classes) with enhanced specificity and effectiveness. Antibody formation involves B cell activation upon encountering an antigen. The initial response produces IgM , which can then undergo class switching to produce other antibody types like IgG, IgA, and IgE. This process is crucial for mounting an effective immune response against pathogens, with IgG being the most abundant antibody in serum and providing long-term immunity. The formation of antibodies, or immunoglobulins involves multiple cellular components and steps: Antigen Encounter and Recognition The process begins when B cells encounter a specific antigen. This antigen must be recognized as foreign to activate the adaptive immune response. B cell receptors (BCRs) on the surface of B cells bind to the antigen. This recognition is highly specific and depends on the unique variable regions of the immunoglobulin on BCRs. Activation of B Cells Upon binding with the antigen, B cells become activated, which requires help from T helper (Th) cells. T cells are required to release cytokines and co-stimulatory signals, which aid in the full activation of B cells, especially in the case of protein antigens. Proliferation and Clonal Expansion Activated B cells undergo clonal expansion, where they proliferate to create identical cells that can produce the same specific antibody. This clonal expansion amplifies the immune response, ensuring that a sufficient number of cells are available to target the pathogen. Differentiation into Plasma Cells and Memory B Cells Following expansion, B cells differentiate into two main cell types: Plasma Cells : These are the effector cells that actively secrete antibodies. Plasma cells are responsible for producing large quantities of antibodies, which are then released into the bloodstream. Memory B Cells : These cells are long-lived and retain the memory of the specific antigen. Upon subsequent exposure to the same antigen, memory B cells can quickly initiate a secondary immune response, leading to a faster and more robust production of antibodies. Antibody Class Switching Initially, B cells produce IgM antibodies. However, with the help of Th cells, B cells can undergo a process called "class switching" to produce other types of antibodies like IgG, IgA, or IgE. Class switching allows the immune system to adapt the type of antibody produced to the specific requirements of the immune response, depending on the nature of the pathogen and the location of the infection. Affinity Maturation Affinity maturation occurs in the germinal centers of lymphoid tissues and involves the somatic hypermutation of antibody genes. This process leads to the production of antibodies with increased affinity for the antigen, allowing for a more effective immune response. Memory and Long-Term Immunity Memory B cells generated during the primary response ensure long-term immunity. If the same antigen is encountered again, these cells quickly respond by differentiating into plasma cells and producing antibodies. This secondary immune response is usually faster

questions.question: A 5-year-old child presents with a sore throat, fever, and swollen lymph nodes. A throat swab confirms a bacterial infection. As part of the immune response, cells in the lymph nodes begin processing and presenting bacterial antigens to activate CD4+ T helper cells. Which of the following cells is primarily responsible for presenting antigens to CD4+ T helper cells?
questions.explanation: and process antigens and present them on MHC class II molecules to CD4+ T helper cells. This interaction is essential for T cell activation and subsequent adaptive immune responses. Other APCs include macrophages and B cells, but dendritic cells are the most potent in activating naïve T cells. Features of Antigen-Presenting Cells: APCs are specialized immune cells that capture, process, and present antigens on their surface to T cells, facilitating the initiation of an immune response. Types of APCs : The primary types include dendritic cells (most potent), macrophages, and B cells, each with unique roles in antigen processing. Location : APCs are located in peripheral tissues, lymph nodes, and the spleen, where they encounter pathogens. Mechanism of Antigen Processing and Presentation: Antigen Uptake : APCs ingest pathogens or pathogen-derived proteins via phagocytosis, endocytosis, or pinocytosis. Dendritic cells are particularly efficient in capturing antigens in peripheral tissues and migrating to lymph nodes. Antigen Processing : The internalized antigen undergoes enzymatic processing within the APC, where it is fragmented into peptide segments. These peptide fragments are then loaded onto major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules within the APC. Antigen Presentation : The processed antigen-MHC complex is transported to the cell surface. MHC Class I molecules present antigens to CD8+ T cells (cytotoxic T cells), while MHC Class II molecules present to CD4+ T cells (helper T cells). Functions: Activation of T Cells : By presenting antigens, APCs activate T cells, a crucial step in adaptive immunity. CD4+ T cells assist other immune cells, while CD8+ T cells directly destroy infected cells. Immune Memory Formation : APCs are integral in the formation of immunological memory, allowing for a faster response upon re-exposure to the same pathogen. Cytokine Production : APCs release cytokines that further modulate immune responses, enhancing the activation and proliferation of T cells. APC Types and Their Unique Roles: Professional APC's: Dendritic Cells : Most potent APCs. They are essential for initiating T-cell responses and are found in nearly all tissues. Macrophages : These cells primarily act as phagocytes, engulfing pathogens and presenting antigens, especially in inflammatory sites. B Cells : Unique among APCs as they can bind specific antigens through their surface immunoglobulin receptors and are more specialized in interacting with helper T cells. Non-Professional APC's: Thymic epithelial cells Endothelial cells Fibroblasts Erythrocytes (Option A) lack a nucleus and MHC molecules, making them incapable of antigen presentation. Macrophages (Option B) can present antigens via MHC class II but are less efficient than dendritic cells at activating naive CD4+ T cells. Neutrophils (Option D) are involved in innate immunity and lack MHC class II molecules, so they cannot present antigens to T cells.

questions.question: A 24-year-old male presents with muscle weakness, difficulty swallowing, blurred vision, and drooping eyelids. Blood tests reveal antibodies against acetylcholine receptors, suggesting myasthenia gravis. The physician explains that the patient's immune system may be reacting to "self" proteins. Which of the following statements best explains the immunological basis for this autoimmune reaction? T-cell-mediated destruction. response involving helper T-cells and autoantibody production. antigen to helper T-cells. antigens.

options.A: The antigen is presented by MHC Class I molecules to CD8+ T-cells, leading to cytotoxic
options.B: The antigen is presented by MHC Class II molecules to CD4+ T-cells, stimulating an immune
options.C: MHC Class I molecules are found only on professional antigen-presenting cells, which present the
options.D: MHC Class II molecules are present on all nucleated cells and help in presenting intracellular

questions.explanation: stimulating an immune response involving helper T-cells and autoantibody production. the body’s own tissues. This reaction often involves MHC Class II molecules on antigen-presenting cells (APCs) that present "self" antigens (such as acetylcholine receptors in this case) to CD4+ T-cells . The activation of CD4+ T-helper cells can then stimulate B-cells to produce autoantibodies against these "self" proteins, leading to the symptoms observed. Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) and Human Leukocyte Antigen (HLA) Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) : MHC molecules are cell surface proteins that play a role in immune system function by presenting peptide fragments to T-cells. They help the immune system distinguish between self and non-self-antigens. Human Leukocyte Antigen (HLA) : In humans, MHC genes are known as HLA genes (on Chromosome 6p ). They encode the proteins for MHC and are highly polymorphic, meaning there is a high degree of variation in the population, which enables a wide range of antigen presentation and immune response diversity. Classification of MHC : MHC Class I : Found on the surface of almost all nucleated cells, MHC I molecules present endogenous (intracellular) antigens, such as viral or tumor proteins, to CD8+ T-cells (cytotoxic T-cells). The three primary HLA genes for MHC I are HLA-A, HLA-B, and HLA-C. MHC Class II : Primarily expressed on antigen-presenting cells (APCs) like macrophages, dendritic cells, and B-cells, MHC II molecules present exogenous (extracellular) antigens to CD4+ T-cells (helper T-cells). HLA genes for MHC II include HLA-DP, HLA-DQ, and HLA-DR. questions.question: Which of the following statements about Gamma Delta ( γδ ) T cells is not correct?

options.A: They are present in the mucus membranes of the GIT and genitourinary tract.
options.B: They represent 5-10% of all peripheral blood T cells.
options.C: They recognize antigens without the need for MHC presentation.
options.D: They process lipids and peptides only through MHC-dependent pathways.

questions.explanation: γδ T cells represent a small subset of T cells (5-10 %) that possess a distinct TCR composed of γ and δ chains; instead of α / β chains. They lack both CD4 and CD8 molecules. They differ from the conventional α / β T cells by the fact that they do not require antigen processing and MHC presentation of peptides. Instead, they recognize non-peptide antigens like lipids , phosphoantigens , and stress-induced molecules directly through their γδ T-cell receptors . γδ T cells are abundant in mucosal tissues , including the gastrointestinal (GIT) and genitourinary tracts , where they play an important role in tissue surveillance , immune defense , and maintaining homeostasis . . Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology by Apurba Shastry, 3rd Edition, Page 174
